title: HST Affiliated Faculty
summary: Ziv Williams serves as an Associate Professor and HST Affiliated Faculty at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is deeply engaged in the exploration of complex cognition across species, including humans, monkeys, and mice.
fullText: Ziv Williams serves as an Associate Professor and HST Affiliated Faculty at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is deeply engaged in the exploration of complex cognition across species, including humans, monkeys, and mice. His multi-disciplinary approach integrates insights from neuroscience, cognitive science, and biomedical engineering to advance understanding of the neural mechanisms underlying cognitive processes and behavioral responses. With a strong commitment to both teaching and research, Williams contributes to the academic community by mentoring students and collaborating with colleagues across various departments. Dr. Williams's research is centered on the development and application of neural prosthetics and functional restoration techniques, particularly in the context of deep brain stimulation and neural modeling. His work has significant implications for treating neurological disorders and enhancing cognitive function, making strides in how we approach brain-computer interfaces and rehabilitation strategies. With a robust expertise in the interplay between neural circuitry and cognitive function, Ziv Williams is a leading figure in the fields of cognitive neuroscience and neural engineering, contributing valuable insights that bridge theoretical knowledge and practical application.
dlc: Harvard-MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology

title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
summary: Yufei Zhao is an Associate Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he engages in advanced research and teaching in various mathematical disciplines.
fullText: Yufei Zhao is an Associate Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he engages in advanced research and teaching in various mathematical disciplines. With a focus on combinatorics and its applications, Professor Zhao has made significant contributions to the understanding of complex mathematical structures and their relationships. His work often intersects with theoretical computer science and discrete mathematics, showcasing his ability to bridge multiple fields and foster interdisciplinary collaboration. Professor Zhao has published extensively in reputable journals, contributing valuable insights that have advanced the field of mathematics. His research interests include graph theory, extremal combinatorics, and probabilistic methods, among others. Through his teaching, he inspires students to explore the depths of mathematical theory while applying quantitative reasoning to real-world problems. With a commitment to academic excellence and innovation, Yufei Zhao continues to be a pivotal figure at MIT, shaping the next generation of mathematicians and researchers.

title: Breene M Kerr (1951) Professor of Nuclear Science and Engineering
summary: Yildiz Group's research focuses on laying the scientific groundwork and proof-of-principle material systems for the next generation of high-efficiency devices for energy conversion and information processing, based on solid state ionic-electronic material
fullText: Bilge Yildiz is the Breene M Kerr (1951) Professor of Nuclear Science and Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she is recognized for her pioneering work in electrochemical materials and interfaces. With a focus on advancing the scientific foundation for next-generation high-efficiency devices, Professor Yildiz leads the Yildiz Group, which is dedicated to exploring innovative solid-state ionic-electronic materials. Her research aims to establish proof-of-principle material systems that can significantly enhance energy conversion and information processing technologies. Professor Yildiz's contributions to the fields of electrochemical energy conversion, including fuel cells and electrolyzers, as well as electrochemical energy storage through solid-state batteries, are exemplary of her expertise. Additionally, her work in neuromorphic computing materials and redox-based memristive information storage has positioned her as a leader in the development of cutting-edge technologies that integrate energy efficiency with advanced computational capabilities. Through her research, Professor Yildiz continues to drive advancements that are critical for the future of sustainable energy and information systems.

title: Principal Research Scientist
summary: Magnetic Fusion: Heating, current drive, and transport, in toroidal devices, induced by radio frequency waves (ion cyclotron, lower hybrid, and electron cyclotron). Parametric wave processes in the plasma edge. Inertial Confinement Fusion: Laser-plasm
fullText: Abhay Ram is a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the intricate field of Magnetic Fusion and Inertial Confinement Fusion. With a focus on the heating, current drive, and transport mechanisms in toroidal devices, Abhay conducts pioneering research into the effects of radio frequency waves, including ion cyclotron, lower hybrid, and electron cyclotron interactions. His work also delves into the parametric wave processes occurring at the plasma edge, contributing significantly to the understanding of energy confinement and plasma behavior in fusion environments. With a robust expertise in electromagnetic wave-plasma interactions, Abhay's research encompasses a wide range of topics, including radiofrequency heating, wave scattering, and nonlinear dynamics. He is particularly known for his investigations into wave-particle interactions in plasmas and the dynamics of plasma waves, which are critical for advancing fusion energy research. Through his contributions, Abhay plays a vital role in MIT’s ongoing efforts to enhance the viability of fusion as a sustainable energy source, positioning him as a key figure in the pursuit of innovative solutions for future energy challenges.

title: Senior Research Scientist
summary: Paul Bonoli specializes in theoretical and computational plasma physics in the areas of radio-frequency (RF) heating and current drive in toroidal confinement devices (tokamaks). He has developed detailed simulation models for RF heating and current drive
fullText: Paul Bonoli serves as a Senior Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is a leading expert in theoretical and computational plasma physics. His work primarily focuses on radio-frequency (RF) heating and current drive in toroidal confinement devices, particularly tokamaks, which are essential for advancing fusion energy research. With a strong foundation in high-performance computing, Bonoli has developed sophisticated simulation models that enhance the understanding of RF heating mechanisms and their implications for plasma stability and confinement. Throughout his career, Bonoli has made significant contributions to the field of plasma physics, particularly through his innovative approaches to RF-wave particle interactions. His expertise encompasses the theory and computation of these interactions, leading to advancements in the efficiency of RF heating systems used in tokamak operations. By leveraging high-performance computing capabilities, he continues to push the boundaries of what is possible in plasma simulations, helping to pave the way for future breakthroughs in fusion energy technology.
tags: High Performance Computing Simulations of RF - Wave Particle Interactions
Theory and Computation of Radio-Frequency Wave-Particle Interactions

title: Principal Research Scientist
summary: Dr. Wright has been interested in fusion since his days as an undergraduate in the Applied Physics program at Columbia University. He received his PhD in Astrophysics at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory and served a post-doc in the Physics Departme
fullText: John Wright is a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the development and application of advanced radiofrequency systems for fusion energy research. With a robust background in astrophysics and plasma physics, Dr. Wright has dedicated his career to exploring innovative solutions for harnessing fusion as a sustainable energy source. His academic journey began at Columbia University, where he pursued an undergraduate degree in Applied Physics, culminating in a PhD from the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory. His extensive experience includes a postdoctoral fellowship in the Physics Department, where he further honed his expertise in multiphysics modeling and RF modeling. Dr. Wright's research focuses primarily on the intricacies of fusion plasma behavior and the optimization of radiofrequency heating systems. His work has significantly contributed to the understanding of plasma confinement and stability, essential factors in the pursuit of practical fusion energy. Additionally, he is well-versed in the complexities of multiphysics simulations that integrate various physical phenomena, allowing for more accurate predictions and designs in fusion experiments. As a thought leader in his field, Dr. Wright continues to advance the boundaries of fusion research, fostering collaborations that aim to translate theoretical advancements into real-world energy solutions.

title: Research Scientist
summary: Darin Ernst is a Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he specializes in the fields of physics research and fusion theory and computation.
fullText: Darin Ernst is a Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he specializes in the fields of physics research and fusion theory and computation. With a robust academic foundation and extensive experience in plasma physics, Darin is dedicated to advancing the understanding of complex plasma behavior in magnetic fusion systems. His work significantly contributes to the development of next-generation fusion energy technologies, aiming to achieve sustainable and efficient energy solutions. Darin's research primarily focuses on the theory and simulation of turbulence in plasma systems, exploring critical phenomena such as internal transport barriers and plasma rotation. His expertise extends to the study of zonal flows and neoclassical transport, which are essential for optimizing plasma confinement and stability in fusion reactors. Additionally, he investigates the effects of radiation on plasma dynamics, further enriching the field's knowledge base and paving the way for innovative approaches to fusion energy. Through his contributions, Darin plays a pivotal role in MIT's research initiatives, collaborating with a diverse team of scientists and engineers to address the challenges of harnessing fusion energy for practical use.
tags: Neoclassical Transport in Magnetic Fusion Plasmas

title: Senior Scientist and Department Chair, Physical Oceanography
summary: Robert Weller is a Senior Scientist and Department Chair in the Physical Oceanography department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Woods Hole, Massachusetts.
fullText: Robert Weller is a Senior Scientist and Department Chair in the Physical Oceanography department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Woods Hole, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career dedicated to advancing the understanding of ocean dynamics, Weller specializes in wind-forced motion in the upper ocean, mixed layer dynamics, and the velocity structure of the upper ocean. His work is crucial in understanding the complex interactions between the ocean and atmosphere, particularly in how these interactions influence climate and weather patterns. Weller's research contributions are marked by his innovative approach to air-sea interaction and his development of advanced instrumentation. He has played a pivotal role in the design and implementation of current meters and surface meteorological instrumentation for air-sea experiments, significantly enhancing the accuracy of air-sea flux measurements. His expertise extends to the study of air-sea fluxes, which are critical for understanding energy transfer between the ocean and atmosphere. Through his leadership and research, Robert Weller continues to contribute valuable insights that inform both scientific knowledge and practical applications in oceanography.

title: Robert A Swanson (1969) Career Development Associate Professor of Life Sciences
summary: The Vos Lab studies how transcription and genome organization are physically coupled using structural biology and biochemistry. This includes X-ray crystallography, cryo-EM, and biophysical approaches. Professor Vos uses X-ray crystallography, cryo-ele
fullText: Seychelle Vos is the Robert A. Swanson (1969) Career Development Associate Professor of Life Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). In her role as an Associate Professor, she is dedicated to advancing the understanding of molecular biology through her innovative research in transcription and genome organization. Professor Vos leads the Vos Lab, where her team employs cutting-edge techniques in structural biology and biochemistry, including X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), and various biophysical approaches to explore the intricate relationships between transcription mechanisms and the spatial organization of the genome. Professor Vos's work is pivotal in elucidating the physical coupling of transcription processes with genome architecture, providing insights that are essential for understanding cellular function and regulation. Her research contributions not only enhance the fundamental knowledge of molecular biology but also have implications for various fields, including genetics and biotechnology. With her expertise in structural methods, she is at the forefront of scientific discovery, making significant strides in revealing how the physical properties of DNA and associated proteins influence gene expression and cellular behavior.

title: Clarence J Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering
summary: Although he joined the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department in Fall 2006, Professor Palacios has been working on wide bandgap semiconductors for the last 8 years. These semiconductors are, probably, the most complete semiconductor family
fullText: Tomas Palacios is the Clarence J. Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). He has been a valued member of the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department since Fall 2006, bringing over a decade of expertise in the field of wide bandgap semiconductors. His work focuses on the design, processing, and characterization of novel electronic devices, particularly those utilizing wide bandgap materials such as gallium nitride (GaN), aluminum gallium nitride (AlGaN), and indium gallium nitride (InGaN). Professor Palacios has established himself as a leading researcher in the development of advanced transistors, including MOSFETs, MESFETs, MISFETs, JFETs, HEMTs, MODFETs, and HFETs, integrating his knowledge of III-V semiconductor technologies. His contributions to the field have significantly advanced the understanding and application of these materials, enhancing their performance in various electronic and optoelectronic devices. Through his innovative research, Professor Palacios continues to push the boundaries of semiconductor technology, making significant strides in the enhancement of device efficiency and functionality.
tags: Processing and Characterization of Novel Electronic Devices in Wide Bandgap Semiconductors and Graphene
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

fullText: Dr. Jeroen Audenaert is a Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive expertise in machine learning, artificial intelligence, and astrophysics to advance innovative research initiatives. With a strong background in both academia and industry, he co-founded Yellowleaf, a digital agency, and played a pivotal role in its growth and success over nearly eight years, culminating in a strategic acquisition by an industry partner. Dr. Audenaert’s unique blend of entrepreneurial experience and scientific acumen positions him as a valuable contributor to the intersection of technology and research. His contributions are not only significant to astrophysics but also have broader implications for the development of AI technologies, underscoring his commitment to fostering innovation at the nexus of science and technology.

title: Research Scientist
summary: David Principe's research is focused on multiwavelength observations of young stars and their planet-forming disks. He reduces and analyzes data from telescopes sensitive to emission in the radio, infrared, optical, and X-ray wavelengths to investigate wh
fullText: David Principe is a Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the field of astrophysics with a particular focus on the multiwavelength observations of young stars and their planet-forming disks. With a robust background in data analysis, he adeptly reduces and interprets data obtained from various telescopes that operate across the radio, infrared, optical, and X-ray wavelengths. His research aims to deepen the understanding of star formation processes and the conditions that lead to the development of planetary systems. Throughout his career, David has made significant contributions to the field of high-energy astrophysics, utilizing advanced observational techniques to explore the dynamics and characteristics of nascent stellar environments. His expertise encompasses a wide range of areas, including Chandra X-ray Observatory data analysis, Magellan Radio Astronomy, and Optical/IR Astronomy. David's innovative approach and commitment to collaborative research continue to enhance the scientific community's knowledge of stellar evolution and the intricate processes involved in the formation of planets.

title: David Austin Professor of Management
summary: Professor Aral’s ground-breaking study on the spread of fake news (The spread of true and false news online) was featured on the cover of Science in March 2018 and shared broadly across global media. His most recent research will be published in September
fullText: Sinan Aral is the David Austin Professor of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he has established himself as a leading authority in the fields of information technology, social contagion, and consumer behavior. As a full professor, he is dedicated to advancing the understanding of how information spreads in digital environments and how social networks influence decision-making and productivity. His research has made significant contributions to the fields of marketing and management, particularly in the context of measuring product virality and consumer demand. Professor Aral's groundbreaking work on the spread of true and false news online gained widespread recognition when it was featured on the cover of Science in March 2018. This pivotal study not only shed light on the mechanisms behind misinformation dissemination but also prompted global discussions about the implications of fake news on society. His current research, set to be published in September, promises to further explore the dynamics of information sharing and its impact on social behavior. With a robust expertise in information technology, social networks, and information worker productivity, Professor Aral continues to be at the forefront of research that bridges the gap between technology and human interaction in the digital age.

fullText: Professor Leslie Kolodziejski serves as the Joseph F. and Nancy P. Keithley Professor in Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). As a full professor, he brings extensive expertise in photonic and opto-electronic structures, epitaxial growth, and device fabrication. His academic and research endeavors have positioned him as a leading figure in the fields of compound semiconductor materials and opto-electronic devices, where he focuses on the development and application of novel heterostructures. Together with Dr. Gale Petrich, Professor Kolodziejski directs the Integrated Photonics Devices and Materials Research Group and oversees the NanoPrecision Deposition Laboratory at MIT. Their research group is at the forefront of pioneering advancements in integrated photonics, exploring innovative approaches to device physics and heteroepitaxial growth processes. Professor Kolodziejski's contributions to the field have significantly enhanced the understanding and capabilities of electronic and opto-electronic materials, making a profound impact on the development of next-generation photonic devices.

summary: Jeffrey Shapiro is the Julius A.
fullText: Jeffrey Shapiro is the Julius A. Stratton Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is recognized for his pioneering work in optical and quantum communications. With a distinguished career spanning several decades, Professor Shapiro has made significant contributions to the fields of optical propagation, sensing systems, and radar. His extensive research encompasses the development and application of advanced technologies in atmospheric optical communications, as well as groundbreaking work in quantum teleportation and entanglement generation at optical frequencies. A leading expert in his field, Professor Shapiro's research focuses on harnessing the principles of quantum mechanics to enhance communication systems and improve sensing capabilities. His innovative approaches and insights have not only advanced the academic understanding of quantum optics but have also paved the way for practical applications in telecommunications and remote sensing. Through his work, he continues to influence the evolution of technologies that leverage the unique properties of light and quantum phenomena, positioning MIT at the forefront of cutting-edge research in electrical engineering and optics.

fullText: Gregory Wornell serves as the Sumitomo Electric Industries Professor in Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he holds the position of Full Professor. With a distinguished academic career, Professor Wornell is recognized for his extensive expertise in signal processing, communication networks, and information theory. His work has made significant contributions to the development of algorithms and architectures that enhance wireless networks, broadband systems, and multimedia environments, positioning him as a thought leader in the field. Professor Wornell's research interests are diverse and encompass critical areas such as signal and information manipulation, wireless networks, and interference cancellation techniques. He has also made notable advancements in multimedia content authentication and source coding algorithms. His work integrates information-theoretic principles with algorithmic aspects of inference and learning, particularly in communication contexts. title: Eaton-Peabody Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
summary: Professor Adalsteinsson's current research interests include algorithms and hardware for parallel transmission (pTx), quantitative estimation and management of local power deposition and temperature in MRI, imaging of the fetus and placenta, oxygenation p
fullText: Elfar Adalsteinsson is the Eaton-Peabody Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career as a full professor, he has established himself as a leading expert in the fields of medical imaging and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). His work is characterized by a strong emphasis on the development of algorithms and hardware designed for parallel transmission (pTx), as well as innovative methods for the quantitative estimation and management of local power deposition and temperature in MRI applications. Professor Adalsteinsson's current research interests span several critical areas, including the imaging of the fetus and placenta, oxygenation, and neuro-imaging. He is particularly focused on methods for optimal acquisition, reconstruction, and processing of in vivo imaging data, which has significant implications for advancing medical diagnostics and treatment. His expertise encompasses data sampling and special encoding, low-level signals, chemical shift imaging, and the study of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's. Through his contributions, Professor Adalsteinsson continues to push the boundaries of medical imaging technology, enhancing both clinical practices and our understanding of complex biological systems.

Her research has significantly contributed to the understanding of electron transport phenomena in one-dimensional interacting systems, positioning her as a leading figure in nanomaterials and their applications in next-generation technologies. Throughout her career, Professor Kong has pioneered innovative chemical vapor deposition methods and developed graphene electrodes for various applications, including organic electronic devices. Her expertise encompasses a wide range of topics, including quantum transport phenomena and the integration of organic molecules into nanoscale systems. fullText: Vincent Chan is the Joan and Irwin Jacobs Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science as well as Aeronautics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he brings extensive expertise in optical networks, satellite networks, and proactive wireless networks, positioning him as a leading figure in the field of communications and network technologies. His academic and research endeavors are characterized by a commitment to advancing knowledge through innovative system designs, architecture, and testbed implementations. His pioneering contributions to these areas have been recognized with numerous accolades, including the prestigious IEEE Thomas Edison Medal for 2024. Professor Chan's work not only addresses contemporary challenges in optical and wireless communications but also anticipates future technological needs, making significant strides in the development of new communication and network technologies.

fullText: John Rice is a Senior Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in advanced X-Ray diagnostics, particularly for the SPARC project, as well as conducting transport experiments on the C-Mod and WEST fusion facilities. With a deep commitment to enhancing the understanding of plasma physics, he has made significant contributions to the fields of atomic physics and high-energy plasma behavior, focusing on the dynamics of highly ionized high-Z materials and their implications for fusion energy applications. Dr. Rice's research encompasses a range of critical areas, including intrinsic rotation, impurity dynamics, and momentum and energy transport within fusion plasmas. His expertise in atomic physics allows him to analyze and interpret complex interactions in high-temperature plasma environments, which are essential for the development of efficient fusion reactors. Through his work, he continues to advance the scientific community's knowledge of plasma behavior, contributing to MIT's leadership in fusion research and its potential for sustainable energy solutions.

fullText: Dr. Johan Frenje is a Senior Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in High-Energy-Density Plasmas (HEDP), Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF), and nuclear physics. fullText: John Tsitsiklis is the Clarence J. LeBel Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he leverages his extensive knowledge in systems, optimization, control, and operations research to advance the field and educate the next generation of engineers and computer scientists. With a prolific publication record that includes over 70 journal papers, Tsitsiklis has made significant contributions to both theoretical and practical applications in his areas of expertise. His research encompasses a wide range of topics, including analysis, optimization, and algorithms for both deterministic and stochastic systems. He is particularly noted for his work in network resource allocation, decentralized detection, data fusion, and consensus and averaging. Additionally, Tsitsiklis has co-authored the influential book "Parallel and Distributed Computation: Numerical Methods," which highlights his commitment to advancing computational techniques in parallel and distributed systems. Through his focused research and dedication to education, John Tsitsiklis continues to shape the landscape of electrical engineering and computer science at MIT and beyond.

fullText: Dimitri Bertsekas is the McAfee Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career as a full professor, he has established himself as a leading authority in optimization theory and its diverse applications across communication and control systems. His work integrates both theoretical and practical elements, making significant contributions to the fields of linear and nonlinear programming, network optimization, dynamic programming, and neuro-dynamic optimization. Professor Bertsekas's research focuses on large-scale optimization and its relevance in various domains, including communication networks and control systems. His expertise encompasses nonlinear optimization and convex analysis, as well as dynamic programming and stochastic control, where he has developed innovative methodologies that advance the understanding and implementation of these concepts. Additionally, he is recognized for his contributions to parallel and distributed algorithms, which play a crucial role in enhancing computational efficiency in optimization tasks. Through his extensive research and academic leadership, Professor Bertsekas continues to influence the evolution of optimization techniques and their practical applications in engineering and technology.

title: Alexander W. Dreyfoos (1954) Professor in Media Arts and Sciences
summary: Joseph Paradiso is the Alexander W.
fullText: Joseph Paradiso is the Alexander W. Dreyfoos (1954) Professor in Media Arts and Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he is recognized for his pioneering work in sensor networks and energy harvesting, contributing significantly to the technical foundation of ubiquitous computing. His leadership in the field has positioned him as a key figure in advancing the integration of physical and digital environments through innovative technologies. Professor Paradiso's research encompasses a variety of cutting-edge projects, including the development of Chain API, Circuit Stickers, and platforms like DoppelLab, which focuses on experiencing multimodal sensor data. He is also the creator of Doppelmarsh, a cross-reality environmental sensor data browser that facilitates the exploration of real-time environmental data. His expertise spans multiple domains, including power management, experiential design, and the practical applications of sensor technology, making him a valuable resource in both academic and industry partnerships.

title: Professor of Media Arts and Sciences
summary: Professor Herr's research program seeks to advance technologies that promise to accelerate the merging of body and machine, including device architectures that resemble the body's musculoskeletal design, actuator technologies that behave like muscle, and
fullText: Hugh Herr is a Professor of Media Arts and Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Renowned for his innovative contributions to the fields of neuroengineering and assistive technology, Herr leads a research program dedicated to advancing the integration of body and machine. His work focuses on developing device architectures that emulate the human musculoskeletal system and actuator technologies that function like biological muscles, aiming to enhance human mobility and interaction with technology. Professor Herr's research encompasses a wide range of interdisciplinary areas, including sensorimotor physiology and engineering, biomaterials, and tissue engineering. He is particularly noted for his pioneering efforts in the development of human assistive technologies that improve locomotory control in mammals, bridging the gap between biological systems and engineered solutions. His expertise also extends to neural and muscular tissue interface engineering and robotics, positioning him as a leading figure in the quest to create advanced technologies that augment human capabilities. Through his work, Professor Herr continues to inspire innovations that have the potential to transform the lives of individuals with disabilities and redefine the relationship between humans and machines.
tags: Neural and Muscular Tissue Interface Engineering

Professor Adib's research is centered on three interconnected themes: he investigates the attenuation of radio frequency signals inside living tissue to enhance sensing capabilities within the human body, develops new techniques for wireless communication in underwater environments, and explores the broader implications of these technologies on wireless systems. Through his pioneering work, he has contributed significantly to the understanding of wireless signals in complex environments, positioning himself as a leader in the field. His expertise not only encompasses advanced communication systems but also extends to interdisciplinary applications that intersect technology, healthcare, and environmental science.

title: Professor of Media Arts and Sciences
summary: When used by people, words are symbolic reflections of rich mental networks that encode knowledge of the physical and social world. Beneath words and sentences lie complex cognitive structures shaped by evolutionary and lifetime learning, linked in variou
fullText: Deb Roy is a Professor of Media Arts and Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career focused on the intersection of language, cognition, and technology, he leverages his extensive expertise to explore the intricate ways in which words serve as symbolic reflections of the rich mental networks that encode knowledge about the physical and social world. His work delves into the complex cognitive structures that underlie language, shaped by both evolutionary processes and individual learning experiences. Roy's research contributions are particularly notable in the fields of language acquisition, artificial intelligence, and human-machine interaction. He investigates the mechanisms of speech recognition and synthesis, advancing the understanding of spoken language and its comprehension by machines. His expertise extends to cognitive modeling, machine learning, and computer vision, where he applies multimedia indexing and retrieval techniques to enhance cognitive machines' capabilities. Through his innovative research, Roy is making significant strides in bridging the gap between human communication and artificial intelligence, positioning him as a leader in the development of technologies that facilitate more natural and effective human-computer interactions.

fullText: Deblina Sarkar is the AT&T Career Development Associate Professor of Media Arts and Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she leads the Nano-Cybernetic Biotrek Lab. In her role, she integrates the fields of nanoelectronics, physics, and biology to pioneer innovative technologies that push the boundaries of what is possible at the intersection of these disciplines. Her work not only explores the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics but also translates these concepts into practical applications, resulting in advancements such as ultra-thin quantum transistors and the development of the first antenna capable of operating within living cells. Professor Sarkar's research focuses on creating novel biocompatible devices that enhance our understanding of biological systems and enable new methods of communication within them. By harnessing the unique properties of nanomaterials and leveraging her expertise in both theoretical and experimental approaches, she is at the forefront of a transformative area of study that combines engineering and life sciences. Her contributions are critical in advancing the potential for future applications in healthcare, biotechnology, and smart materials, making her a leading figure in the field of media arts and sciences at MIT.

summary: Dr. Shinn’s primary line of investigation is to better understand auditory hallucinations in psychotic disorders. While psychosis research has traditionally focused on diagnostic categories like schizophrenia, which are heterogeneous and may consist of mu
fullText: Dr. Ann Shinn serves as an Assistant Professor and HST Affiliated Faculty at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she leverages her extensive expertise in psychosis, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder to advance the understanding of complex mental health conditions. With a strong foundation in psychopathology, Dr. Shinn's work is characterized by a commitment to uncovering the underlying mechanisms of auditory hallucinations, a prevalent symptom in various psychotic disorders. Her research aims to move beyond traditional diagnostic categories, such as schizophrenia, which often encompass a heterogeneous array of symptoms and experiences. Dr. Shinn's pioneering contributions to the field focus on elucidating the nature and impact of hallucinations and delusions, thereby enhancing the understanding of how these experiences manifest across different psychotic conditions. By employing innovative research methodologies, she seeks to identify the neurobiological and psychological factors that contribute to these phenomena, ultimately informing more effective treatment strategies. Her expertise not only encompasses the clinical aspects of psychosis but also extends to the intricate interplay between mental health disorders and their broader societal implications.

title: William R Kenan, Jr Professor of Earth and Planetary Sciences
summary: Professor McGee seeks to understand how Earth’s climate evolves over time. Through a range of collaborative projects, my group examines the ways that rainfall patterns, winds, permafrost, and other parts of the Earth system have responded to natural clima
fullText: David McGee is the William R. Kenan, Jr. Professor of Earth and Planetary Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he is recognized for his profound contributions to the field of geochronology, specializing in the understanding of Earth's climate evolution over time. His research emphasizes the examination of geological processes and their implications for climate dynamics, focusing on timescales ranging from 10,000 to 500,000 years. Professor McGee's expertise lies in the slow decay of radioactive materials, primarily uranium and thorium, which he utilizes to unravel historical climate patterns and environmental changes. Through a series of collaborative projects, Professor McGee’s research group investigates the intricate interactions between various components of the Earth system, including rainfall patterns, atmospheric winds, and permafrost dynamics. His work aims to enhance the understanding of how these elements respond to natural climate variability, providing valuable insights into past and future climate scenarios. His contributions not only advance the scientific community's comprehension of geochronology but also offer critical perspectives on the implications of climate change, positioning him as a leading figure in the intersection of Earth sciences and environmental policy.

title: HST Affiliated Faculty
summary: Gastrointestinal cancers are highly lethal cancers where the vast majority of patients are diagnosed too late and conventional therapies have largely been ineffective, making early detection and novel drug targets greatly needed. The Ting laboratory has b
fullText: David Tsai Ting is an Associate Professor affiliated with the Harvard-MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology (HST). He is recognized for his expertise in the field of gastrointestinal cancers, particularly pancreatic cancer, which is known for its high lethality and late diagnosis. Dr. Ting's research is dedicated to addressing the urgent need for early detection methods and novel therapeutic targets in this challenging area of oncology. His laboratory leverages cutting-edge techniques such as single-cell analysis and spatial transcriptomics to explore the complexities of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), aiming to uncover critical insights that could lead to improved patient outcomes. Dr. Ting's contributions to the understanding of repeat RNAs and their role in cancer biology are noteworthy, as they offer a promising avenue for the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. His work not only advances the scientific community's understanding of pancreatic cancer but also has the potential to significantly impact clinical practices. With a strong focus on integrating innovative technologies into cancer research, Dr. Ting continues to push the boundaries of traditional approaches, making him a valuable asset to both the academic and medical fields.

title: Technical Associate I
summary: Dr. Godoy has a strong background in immunology, having worked extensively on a mouse model of a systemic mycosis during his PhD training. During his postdoctoral experience, he has studied the involvement of nitric oxide in cell signaling in several cont
fullText: Luiz Godoy is a Technical Associate I at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he contributes to cutting-edge research as a Research Associate. With a robust background in immunology, Dr. Godoy brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise to his role, focusing on the intricate mechanisms of immune responses and their implications for disease treatment and prevention. Dr. Godoy's doctoral research centered on a mouse model of systemic mycosis, where he explored the pathophysiology of fungal infections and the immune system's response to them. His postdoctoral work has further advanced the field by investigating the role of nitric oxide in cell signaling, examining its impact on various cellular processes and how it mediates immune responses. Through his research, Dr. Godoy has made significant contributions to understanding the complexities of immunological signaling pathways, paving the way for potential therapeutic advancements in infectious diseases and immune-related disorders.

title: Whitehead Career Development Assistant Professor of Biology
summary: Professor Knouse's lab seeks to understand how tissues sense and respond to damage with the long-term goal of developing novel approaches for regenerative medicine. Focus is on the mammalian liver, which has the unique ability to completely regenerate its
fullText: Kristin Knouse is the Whitehead Career Development Assistant Professor of Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). In her role, she is dedicated to advancing the understanding of tissue biology, with a particular emphasis on the mechanisms by which tissues sense and respond to damage. Her expertise lies in the regenerative capabilities of the mammalian liver, an organ renowned for its remarkable ability to fully regenerate after injury. Through her innovative research, Professor Knouse aims to uncover fundamental biological processes that could inform the development of novel regenerative medicine strategies. Professor Knouse's lab investigates the intricate signaling pathways and cellular responses involved in liver regeneration, seeking to translate findings into therapeutic applications. Her work not only contributes to the broader field of regenerative biology but also has potential implications for treating liver diseases and enhancing tissue repair mechanisms in various medical contexts. With a commitment to scientific excellence and collaboration, Professor Knouse is poised to make significant contributions to both academia and the biomedical industry.

summary: Recent works includes a new opera by Israeli composer Na’ama Zisser titled Mamzer/Bastard at the Royal Opera House in London and the multiplatform Platonov, or the Disinherited, which premiered as part of the Without Walls Festival at La Jolla Playhouse f
fullText: Jay Scheib is the Class of 1949 Professor of Theater Arts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he holds the position of Full Professor. Based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, Scheib is a prominent figure in the field of theater, recognized for his innovative approach to performance and interdisciplinary collaborations. His work integrates technology and storytelling, pushing the boundaries of traditional theater to create immersive experiences for audiences. Recent highlights of Scheib's research include directing a new opera titled Mamzer/Bastard by Israeli composer Na’ama Zisser at the Royal Opera House in London, showcasing his commitment to contemporary works and international collaboration. Additionally, he premiered the multiplatform project Platonov, or the Disinherited, as part of the Without Walls Festival at La Jolla Playhouse, further emphasizing his dedication to experimental theater practices. Through these projects, Scheib continues to explore the intersections of narrative, performance, and technology, making significant contributions to the evolving landscape of theater arts.

The Fujimoto group's research focuses on refining and applying OCT technologies, including swept source OCT and spectral domain OCT, to enhance imaging capabilities in both clinical and research settings. Professor Fujimoto's contributions extend to numerous areas, including photonics, endoscopic imaging, and multiphoton microscopy, where his work has significantly advanced optical biopsy techniques and imaging technology research and development. title: Professor of Biology
summary: Research in the Lehmann Lab focuses on the biology of germ cells. Germ cells are the stem cells for the next generation. Set aside during embryogenesis from the somatic cells that form the body of the organism, germ cells impart the ability to create new
fullText: Ruth Lehmann is a Professor of Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she serves as an Associate Professor and leads the Lehmann Lab. With a distinguished career in developmental genetics, her research primarily focuses on the biology of germ cells, the essential stem cells responsible for the propagation of the next generation. By investigating the intricate mechanisms that set germ cells apart from somatic cells during embryogenesis, Professor Lehmann contributes significantly to our understanding of how germ cells influence the development and continuity of life. In her lab, Professor Lehmann utilizes the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, as a model organism to explore the localization of maternal information and its critical role in embryonic segmentation. Her work encompasses genetic and molecular analyses of maternal effect loci, which elucidate the foundational processes underlying early development. With expertise in both molecular and developmental genetics, she has made impactful contributions to the field, advancing knowledge of germ cell biology and its implications for reproductive health and developmental disorders.

summary: The Varanasi Lab applies a Basic Science Method to solve problems in a diverse set of fields with an emphasis on real-world applications and scale-up. The mission is to solve important challenges in Climate, Energy, Biomedical, Water, Agriculture, Tran
fullText: Kripa Varanasi is a Professor of Mechanical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge, MA. With a robust academic background and extensive expertise in nanoengineered surfaces, Professor Varanasi focuses on developing innovative solutions to pressing global challenges. His research, conducted through the Varanasi Lab, employs a Basic Science Method to tackle critical issues across various fields, including climate change, energy, biomedical applications, water management, and agriculture. Under Professor Varanasi's leadership, the lab has made significant strides in understanding fluid-surface interactions and thermal-fluid-surface dynamics, resulting in advancements in superhydrophobic, superhydrophilic, oleophobic, and oleophilic surfaces. His work not only emphasizes theoretical exploration but also prioritizes real-world applications and scaling solutions for industries such as oil and gas, aviation, and electronics cooling systems. Through his contributions to biomimetics and other innovative domains, Professor Varanasi continues to drive research that bridges the gap between fundamental science and practical engineering, fostering advancements that have the potential to make a lasting impact on society.

title: Assistant Professor of Mathematics

fullText: Tristan Ozuch serves as an Assistant Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he specializes in the field of Geometric Analysis. With a profound understanding of the intricate relationships between geometry and analysis, Professor Ozuch has established himself as a leading expert in the study of Einstein manifolds and Ricci flows, contributing significantly to the theoretical foundations and applications of these areas. His research primarily concentrates on the geometric structures that arise from the interplay of curvature and topology, particularly in the context of Einstein manifolds. By exploring the dynamics of Ricci flows, Professor Ozuch aims to uncover new insights into the geometric properties of manifolds and their evolution under curvature conditions. His work is characterized by a rigorous analytical approach, addressing complex problems in differential geometry and partial differential equations (PDEs). With expertise in Geometric Analysis, Analysis and PDEs, and the study of Einstein manifolds and Ricci flows, Professor Ozuch continues to advance the field through innovative research and collaboration.

fullText: Susumu Tonegawa is the Picower Professor of Biology and Neuroscience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is a leading figure in the study of the mammalian brain. With a distinguished career as a full professor, Dr. Tonegawa has made significant contributions to our understanding of the mechanisms underlying learning and memory, vital processes that influence daily activities ranging from navigation to public speaking. Dr. Tonegawa's expertise extends beyond the realm of neuroscience; he is also well-versed in molecular biology and immunology, with a specific focus on the organization, structure, rearrangements, and expression of immunoglobulin genes. His work has not only advanced the field of neuroscience but has also provided valuable perspectives on cell differentiation mechanisms. Through his pioneering studies, Dr. Tonegawa continues to shape the landscape of biological research, fostering a greater understanding of both brain function and the genetic underpinnings of immune responses.

fullText: Gaia Stucky de Quay is an Assistant Professor of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she leverages her expertise in landscape evolution and topographic signals to advance the understanding of geological processes. Her research focuses on deconvolving and quantifying the primary driving forces behind landscape evolution, including tectonic activity, climatic influences, and local geological phenomena. title: Cecil and Ida Green Professor of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences
summary: Professor Perron studies the physical processes that create landscapes on Earth and other planets. His group's efforts currently follow three themes: the formation and evolution of river networks; the influence of climate on erosion and landscapes; and la
fullText: J Perron is the Cecil and Ida Green Professor of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he serves as a full professor. With a distinguished career in geomorphology and planetary science, Professor Perron specializes in the physical processes that shape landscapes on Earth and other celestial bodies. His academic pursuits are centered around understanding the intricate dynamics of surface processes, including erosion, sediment flow, and deposition, as well as the formation and evolution of river networks. Professor Perron's research encompasses three primary themes: the development and transformation of river networks, the interplay between climate factors and landscape erosion, and the analysis of landforms such as ripples and dunes. His work not only advances scientific knowledge about terrestrial and extraterrestrial landscapes but also addresses critical environmental challenges related to erosion and sediment transport. Through his expertise in landslides, debris flows, and the geomorphological impacts of both land and sea floor processes, Professor Perron contributes valuable insights that inform ongoing research and foster collaboration within the scientific community.
tags: Both Land and the Sea Floor

fullText: Sherry Turkle is the Abby Rockefeller Mauzé Professor of the Social Studies of Science and Technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she is recognized for her pioneering work in the intersection of technology, society, and the individual. With a joint doctorate in sociology and personality psychology from Harvard University, Turkle is also a licensed clinical psychologist, bringing a unique perspective to her analysis of human-technology interactions. Her research delves into the subjective experiences of individuals as they navigate their relationships with technology, exploring how these interactions shape personal identity and social dynamics. Professor Turkle's contributions to the field are extensive, particularly in her examination of the psychological implications of computer-mediated communication and the evolving nature of personal interaction in an increasingly digital world. Her insights into gender and technology, as well as the sociology of science, have positioned her as a thought leader in understanding the impact of technology on society. Key areas of her expertise include the psychology of technology use, identity formation in the context of the internet, and the relationship between people and artifacts, making her work essential for comprehending the complexities of modern technological engagement. Through her research and writing, Turkle continues to influence discussions on how technology reshapes human experience and societal norms.

His research primarily revolves around the development of mathematical techniques that enhance the quantification and prediction of uncertain systems. fullText: Bruce Walker is a Professor of the Practice at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, located in Charlestown, Massachusetts. With extensive experience in the field of immunology, he specializes in adaptive cell immunity and AIDS research, focusing on the immune mechanisms that govern HIV infection. As a leading researcher in his field, he has dedicated his career to understanding the complexities of the immune response to HIV, particularly among individuals who can control the virus without the need for antiretroviral therapy. At the helm of the Walker laboratory, he investigates the unique characteristics of spontaneous HIV controllers, aiming to uncover the fundamental processes that enable these individuals to maintain viral suppression. His research has garnered international attention and is supported by significant funding from the Gates Foundation, facilitating collaborations that seek to advance therapeutic strategies for enhancing antiviral immunity. Walker's work is pivotal in the quest to develop innovative treatments for HIV and his expertise in immune system research positions him as a key contributor to the global fight against AIDS.

summary: Professor Donti work focuses on machine learning for forecasting, optimization, and control in high-renewables power grids. Specifically, her research explores methods to incorporate the physics and hard constraints associated with electric power systems
fullText: Priya Donti is the Silverman (1968) Family Career Development Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). With a strong foundation in machine learning, Professor Donti specializes in the application of advanced computational techniques to address critical challenges in high-renewables power grids. Her work is particularly focused on developing innovative methods for forecasting, optimization, and control, aiming to enhance the efficiency and reliability of electric power systems in the context of increasing renewable energy integration. Through her research, Professor Donti explores the incorporation of physical principles and hard constraints inherent in electric power systems, striving to create robust models that can effectively manage the complexities of modern energy networks. By bridging the gap between theoretical advancements in machine learning and practical applications in energy systems, she contributes significantly to the ongoing transition toward sustainable energy solutions. Professor Donti's expertise encompasses not only machine learning methodologies but also the intricacies of power system dynamics, making her a valuable asset to both the academic community and industry stakeholders engaged in the future of energy systems.

title: President
summary: Sally Kornbluth is President of MIT. Prior to closing her lab at Duke University, her research focused on the biological signals that tell a cell to start dividing or to self-destruct -- processes that are key to understanding cancer as well as various de
fullText: Sally Kornbluth serves as the President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she provides strategic leadership and oversight to one of the world's leading research universities. With a distinguished career in academia, Kornbluth has a profound commitment to advancing education and innovation. Prior to her appointment at MIT, she was a prominent figure at Duke University, where she led a successful research lab dedicated to unraveling the complex biological signals that dictate cell behavior, particularly those that govern cell division and programmed cell death. Kornbluth's research has significantly contributed to the understanding of cellular processes that are critical in the context of cancer and other diseases. Her work has illuminated the mechanisms by which cells receive and respond to signals, providing valuable insights that could lead to new therapeutic strategies. As an accomplished scientist and leader, Kornbluth's expertise encompasses cell biology, cancer research, and the intersection of scientific inquiry and educational leadership, making her a pivotal figure in fostering collaboration between academia and industry. fullText: Volha Charnysh is the Ford International Career Development Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. With a strong foundation in comparative politics and historical political economy, she brings a unique perspective to understanding the intricate dynamics of political behavior and the legacies of violence. Her expertise spans several critical areas, including the political economy of Eastern Europe, the effects of authoritarianism, and the complex interplay between migration and economic development. Charnysh is currently engaged in a significant book project titled "Migration, Diversity, and Economic Development," which investigates the long-term impacts of forced migration in Eastern Europe following World War II. This research sheds light on how historical events shape contemporary political landscapes and economic conditions, particularly in the context of ethnic politics. Through her scholarship, she contributes to a deeper understanding of the historical narratives that inform current political phenomena, including the challenges posed by migration and diversity in the wake of conflict. Her work not only enhances academic discourse but also offers valuable insights for policymakers and organizations navigating the complexities of migration and development in diverse settings.

fullText: Valentin Figueroa is an Assistant Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he specializes in comparative politics with a particular emphasis on historical state-building, ideological change, and scientific innovation. His academic journey has led him to investigate the intricate dynamics of political development in both Western Europe and Latin America, contributing valuable insights to the understanding of how historical contexts shape contemporary governance and policy-making. Professor Figueroa's research critically examines the processes that underlie state formation and transformation, exploring how economic and ideological factors interact to influence political outcomes. With a robust expertise in economic history and a focus on comparative methodologies, he is well-positioned to contribute to ongoing discussions about the evolution of political systems across diverse regions.

fullText: Suzanne Berger serves as the John M. Deutch (1961) Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she is a leading figure in the fields of comparative politics and political economy. Based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, Professor Berger has dedicated her career to exploring the intricate relationships between government and business in advanced industrial societies, with a particular focus on European politics and economies, especially in France and Italy. Her insights into the dynamics of national and international security and globalization have made her a prominent voice in the academic community. Currently, Professor Berger conducts research at the MIT Industrial Performance Center, where she analyzes the globalization strategies of firms across Asia, America, and Europe. Her work not only contributes to the understanding of global competitiveness but also addresses the challenges and opportunities posed by globalization in today's interconnected world. With expertise spanning government-business relations, competitive strategies, and comparative politics, her scholarship provides valuable perspectives on how nations adapt to and shape the global economic landscape.

summary: Professor Nathan's research focuses on electoral politics, political economy, and urban politics in Africa. His first book, Electoral Politics and Africa’s Urban Transition: Class and Ethnicity in Ghana (Cambridge University Press, 2019), examines urbaniz
fullText: Noah Nathan is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he specializes in the political economy of development, comparative political behavior, and urban politics, particularly in the context of Africa. With a keen focus on electoral politics, Professor Nathan brings a wealth of knowledge and insight into the complexities of state-building and distributive politics, emphasizing the roles of political parties and clientelism in shaping governance and civic engagement in urban settings. His research contributions are exemplified in his first book, "Electoral Politics and Africa’s Urban Transition: Class and Ethnicity in Ghana," published by Cambridge University Press in 2019. This work critically examines the dynamics of urbanization in Ghana, analyzing how class and ethnicity influence electoral outcomes and political participation. Professor Nathan's expertise encompasses a range of key areas, including political economy, urban politics, and the intricate relationships between social structures and political behavior, making him a prominent figure in the study of African political systems and their evolution.

title: Professor of Political Science
summary: Dr. Choucri’s research extends the theory of Lateral Pressure, framed earlier with Robert C. North at Stanford University. By highlighting interactions among the driving variables shaping prevailing propensities for expansion -- population, resources, and
fullText: Nazli Choucri is a Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career in academia, Dr. Choucri specializes in national and international security, connectivity and the global environment, and political and economic development, particularly in the Middle East. Her scholarly work is recognized for its depth and impact, addressing complex issues that lie at the intersection of politics, economics, and global relations. Dr. Choucri's research extends the theory of Lateral Pressure, a framework she initially developed in collaboration with Robert C. North at Stanford University. This theory examines the dynamics of population growth, resource availability, and their interplay in shaping national and international expansion. Her contributions also include modeling oil-related challenges and policies, as well as exploring technology transfer to less developed countries. Through her extensive analysis of conflict among nations, Dr. Choucri has provided valuable insights into the factors influencing global stability and cooperation, making her a leading voice in her field.
tags: Political and Economic Development in the Middle East

fullText: Naoki Egami is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and a faculty affiliate of the MIT Institute for Data, Systems, and Society. His interdisciplinary approach combines traditional political analysis with advanced computational techniques, allowing for innovative insights into political behavior and decision-making processes. Professor Egami's research contributions are particularly notable in the areas of causal inference, external validity, and the application of machine learning and artificial intelligence in political analysis. He has explored the implications of large language models and network structures in understanding political phenomena, positioning himself at the forefront of the intersection between data science and political inquiry. His expertise not only enhances the methodological rigor of political research but also fosters collaborative efforts across disciplines, making significant strides in how political data is analyzed and interpreted.

title: Arthur and Ruth Sloan Professor of Political Science
summary: Professor Fravel studies international relations, with a focus on international security, China, and East Asia. He is the author of Strong Borders, Secure Nation: Cooperation and Conflict in China's Territorial Disputes (Princeton University Press, 2008)
fullText: M. Fravel is the Arthur and Ruth Sloan Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise in the field of international relations, with a particular focus on national and international security, East Asia, and the strategic dynamics involving China. His academic contributions are recognized both nationally and internationally, making him a prominent figure in the study of political risk and strategic relations. Professor Fravel's research centers on the complexities of international security, especially concerning territorial disputes and cooperation patterns in East Asia. He is the author of the influential book "Strong Borders, Secure Nation: Cooperation and Conflict in China's Territorial Disputes," published by Princeton University Press in 2008, which examines the interplay between China's territorial claims and its international relations. Through his work, he has significantly advanced the understanding of security issues in East Asia, establishing himself as a leading voice in the analysis of China's role in global politics and the implications for regional stability. His expertise continues to inform policy discussions and scholarly debates on critical security issues in the region.

title: Associate Professor of Political Science
summary: Professor Grinberg's research interests include: why states trade with their enemies; how time and uncertainty shape nations’ strategic decisions; and the process of state decline. She earned a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago in 2019, and has been a
fullText: Mariya Grinberg is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she specializes in the intricate dynamics of international relations and security. With a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago, earned in 2019, Professor Grinberg has established herself as a prominent scholar in the fields of International Relations Theory and Political Economy of Security. Her work is characterized by a keen analytical approach to understanding the motivations and behaviors of states, particularly in contexts of conflict and competition. Professor Grinberg's research delves into several critical issues, including the paradox of why states engage in trade with their adversaries, the influence of time and uncertainty on strategic decision-making, and the complex process of state decline. Her contributions to the understanding of wartime trade and order formation highlight the nuanced interplay between sovereignty and international economic relations. Through her scholarly pursuits, she aims to provide insights that inform both academic discourse and practical policy considerations in international security and economic interactions.

title: Associate Professor of Political Science
summary: Mai Hassan is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she specializes in comparative politics, bureaucracy, and public administration.
fullText: Mai Hassan is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she specializes in comparative politics, bureaucracy, and public administration. With a keen focus on the dynamics of state power and contentious politics, her research examines how state repression manifests in various political contexts, particularly within African and Middle Eastern societies. Through her scholarly work, she contributes to a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between governance structures and societal responses, shedding light on the implications for public policy and political stability. Dr. Hassan's expertise encompasses a broad range of topics, including the role of the state in shaping political behavior, the functioning of bureaucracies, and the factors that drive state repression. Her analytical approach combines theoretical frameworks with empirical research, enabling her to address significant issues within African and Middle Eastern politics. As a thought leader in her field, she actively engages in dialogues about the challenges and opportunities faced by these regions, making her a valuable resource for both academic and policy-oriented discussions.

fullText: Lily Tsai is the Ford Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she specializes in governance, accountability, and the provision of public goods. With a robust academic background and extensive experience in political science, Professor Tsai employs both quantitative and qualitative methodologies to explore the factors that enhance governmental performance and accountability. Her research aims to provide valuable insights into how effective governance can improve the delivery of essential services, thereby contributing to the overall well-being of societies. Professor Tsai's work is particularly focused on state-society relations and comparative politics, with a significant emphasis on Chinese politics. She has made substantial contributions to understanding the dynamics of accountability in governance and has published extensively on the implications of these dynamics for public policy and administration. Her expertise in these areas positions her as a leading voice in discussions surrounding effective governance and the interaction between states and their citizens. Based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, she continues to engage with scholars and practitioners alike to advance knowledge and foster collaboration in the field of political science.

title: Ford International Professor of Social Sciences
summary: Professor Christia's past research has focused on issues of conflict and cooperation in the Muslim world, and I have conducted fieldwork in Afghanistan, Bosnia, Iraq, Iran, the Palestinian Territories, Syria, and Yemen. She is the author of “Alliance Form
fullText: Fotini Christia is the Ford International Professor of Social Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she serves as a full professor in the Department of Political Science. With a distinguished career dedicated to the study of political dynamics in the Muslim world, Professor Christia specializes in civil wars, political violence, identity politics, and post-conflict reconstruction. Her work is characterized by a rigorous approach that combines field experiments and big data analysis to derive insights into complex social and political phenomena. Professor Christia has conducted extensive fieldwork across various conflict zones, including Afghanistan, Bosnia, Iraq, Iran, the Palestinian Territories, Syria, and Yemen. Her research addresses critical issues of conflict and cooperation, contributing to a deeper understanding of the factors that shape alliances and social dynamics in these regions. She is the author of the influential book “Alliance Form,” which explores the intricacies of cooperative behavior in contexts of adversity. Through her scholarly contributions, Professor Christia has established herself as a leading voice in the fields of political science and international relations, with a particular emphasis on the Middle East.
dlc: Institute for Data, Systems and Society

title: Associate Professor of Political Science
summary: Professor Hidalgo's research focuses on political representation and electoral behavior in poor and middle-income democracies, as well as applied quantitative methods in the social sciences. His current substantive research interests include the political
fullText: F. Daniel Hidalgo is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he specializes in understanding political representation and electoral behavior in both poor and middle-income democracies. His academic work employs applied quantitative methods to address pressing issues in the social sciences, providing valuable insights into the dynamics of political systems and voter behavior. With a robust background in political science, Professor Hidalgo is recognized for his expertise in the political consequences of fraud-reducing electoral reforms, the role of money in politics, and the use of violence in elections. Professor Hidalgo's research contributions significantly enhance the understanding of how electoral processes function in varied socio-economic contexts. His investigations into the effectiveness of electoral reforms aimed at reducing fraud reveal critical implications for improving democratic governance. Additionally, his analysis of the influence of financial resources on political campaigns sheds light on the complexities of political equity and representation. By examining the intersection of violence and electoral practices, Professor Hidalgo's work addresses fundamental questions about the integrity of democratic institutions and the conditions under which they thrive. His research not only advances theoretical knowledge but also informs policy discussions aimed at strengthening democratic processes worldwide.
tags: Political Consequences of Fraud-Reducing Electoral Reforms

fullText: Erik Lin-Greenberg is the Leo Marx Career Development Associate Professor in the History and Culture of Science & Technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In his role as an Associate Professor, he brings a unique interdisciplinary approach to understanding the intersection of emerging military technologies and their implications for conflict dynamics and security strategy. His academic background and ongoing research position him as a leading voice in the exploration of how technological advancements shape the regulation and use of force in contemporary warfare. Professor Lin-Greenberg's research is centered on the impact of emerging technologies on crisis escalation and military strategy. He is currently working on a book project that employs a diverse array of methodologies, including experimental methods, archival research, elite interviews, and surveys, to investigate the nuanced relationships between technology and conflict. His expertise extends to critical areas such as security strategy and the ethical considerations surrounding the deployment of new military capabilities. Through his scholarly contributions, Lin-Greenberg aims to inform policy discussions and enhance understanding of the complex dynamics at play in modern conflicts.

fullText: Charles Stewart III is the Kenan Sahin Distinguished Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he has been a faculty member since 1985. With a robust focus on American politics, Stewart's expertise encompasses legislative politics, campaigns and elections, and the broader trajectory of American political development. His extensive experience in these areas has established him as a leading scholar in the field, contributing significantly to the understanding of political behavior and the dynamics of congressional operations. Stewart's research has made impactful contributions to the study of electoral processes and legislative behavior, exploring how institutions shape political outcomes and citizen engagement. He employs rigorous research methods to analyze various aspects of political science, enabling him to offer insights into the complexities of American governance. Through his work, he has not only advanced academic knowledge but has also provided valuable perspectives for policymakers and practitioners in the field of political science, further solidifying his reputation as a key figure in American political research.
