summary: Professor Flemming takes the central task of phonetic and phonological theory to be the development of a theory that delimits the set of possible phonological-phonetic systems, and explains why languages use sound in the way that they do. He is exploring
fullText: Edward Flemming is a Professor of Linguistics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he specializes in the fields of phonology and phonetics. With a distinguished career in linguistic research, Professor Flemming has dedicated his scholarly efforts to understanding the intricate relationship between sound systems and language usage. His work is pivotal in advancing the theoretical frameworks that delineate the possible phonological and phonetic systems across languages, offering insights into why different languages employ sound in unique ways. Professor Flemming's research delves into the core challenges of phonetic and phonological theory, with a focus on developing comprehensive models that account for the diversity of sound patterns observed in human languages. His contributions have significantly enriched the field, providing a deeper understanding of the mechanisms underlying sound organization and the cognitive processes involved in language production and perception. As an expert in phonology and phonetics, he continues to influence both academic discourse and applied linguistics, fostering a greater appreciation for the complexities of human language.

title: Assistant Professor
summary: Elise Newman is an assistant professor in the Department of Linguistics and Philosophy. Her forthcoming monograph, “When arguments merge,” studies the ingredients that languages use to construct verb phrases, and examines how those ingredients interact wi
fullText: Elise Newman is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Linguistics and Philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). With a strong focus on the intersection of syntax, semantics, and language acquisition, she brings a nuanced understanding of how language functions and develops. Her academic journey has equipped her with a rich foundation in the theoretical frameworks that underpin linguistic structure and meaning, making her a valuable asset to the department and the broader linguistic community. Dr. Newman's forthcoming monograph, “When Arguments Merge,” delves into the intricacies of verb phrase construction across languages, offering fresh insights into the elements that contribute to this fundamental aspect of grammar. Through her research, she investigates the dynamic interactions between various linguistic ingredients, shedding light on how they influence language processing and acquisition. Her work not only advances theoretical linguistics but also has implications for understanding cognitive processes related to language. With her expertise in syntax, semantics, and language acquisition, Elise Newman continues to contribute significantly to the field, fostering a deeper comprehension of the complexities of human language.

title: Senior Research Scientist
summary: Smart Grids as a means of implementing sustainable IT-enabled electricity services; Modeling and control of future electric energy systems (transforming hierarchical into open-access systems); Modeling and control of economic, policy and technical interac
fullText: Marija Ilic is a Senior Research Scientist based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, specializing in electric power systems modeling and control. With a robust background in large-scale system analysis, she leverages her expertise to advance the development of sustainable IT-enabled electricity services. Dr. Ilic is particularly focused on the evolution of smart grids, emphasizing their potential to transform traditional hierarchical electricity systems into more open-access frameworks. Her work integrates economic, policy, and technical interactions, addressing the complexities of future electric energy systems. Dr. Ilic's research contributions significantly enhance the understanding and implementation of smart grid technologies. She is adept in the economics of electric power systems, power electronics, and the microprocessor-based control of electric drives, making her a vital asset in the field. Her innovative approaches aim to optimize energy efficiency and promote sustainability within the power sector, positioning her at the forefront of advancements in electric energy systems. Through her work, Dr. Ilic plays a crucial role in shaping the future of energy management and policy, aligning technological innovations with economic and environmental imperatives.

fullText: James LeBeau is a Full Professor of Materials Science and Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leads the LeBeau Group. With a commitment to advancing the field of materials science, Professor LeBeau's research focuses on the intricate relationships between local atomic structure, chemical composition, and the properties of materials at the nanoscale. His research also delves into the development of novel metal alloys, ferroelectrics and piezoelectrics, and nanoscale/2D materials. Through advanced electron microscopy techniques, he probes quantum properties and the mechanisms that underlie material performance, thereby contributing valuable insights to both academia and industry.

title: Victor J Menezes (1972) Career Development Associate Professor of Finance
summary: Professor Schmidt is interested in understanding factors that are associated with the risk and return to investments in human capital, and how frictions that limit risk-sharing in the labor market affect asset prices and macroeconomic dynamics.
fullText: Lawrence Schmidt is the Victor J Menezes (1972) Career Development Associate Professor of Finance at MIT, where he specializes in the intersection of economics, finance, and accounting. With a robust academic background and a commitment to advancing the understanding of financial markets, Professor Schmidt plays a pivotal role in shaping the next generation of finance professionals. His expertise spans several key areas, including macroeconomics and the intricate workings of asset pricing mechanisms. Professor Schmidt's research focuses on the nuanced factors that influence the risk and return associated with investments in human capital. He delves into how market frictions that limit risk-sharing within the labor market can have significant implications for asset prices and broader macroeconomic dynamics. Through his innovative approach and rigorous analysis, he contributes valuable insights that enhance the understanding of investment strategies and economic behavior, making him a respected figure in his field.

title: David H Koch Institute Professor
summary: A major focus of Professor Langer’s research is the study and development of polymers to deliver drugs, particularly genetically engineered proteins and DNA, continuously at controlled rates for prolonged periods of time. Work is in progress in the follow
fullText: Robert Langer is the David H. Koch Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he holds a distinguished position as one of the leading figures in the fields of biomedical engineering and drug delivery. His extensive research primarily revolves around the development of innovative polymers designed to deliver drugs, particularly genetically engineered proteins and DNA, at controlled rates over extended periods. This pioneering work has the potential to revolutionize treatment methodologies across various medical disciplines, particularly in cancer therapy and tissue engineering. As a recognized expert in drug delivery systems, biomaterials, and tissue engineering scaffolds, Professor Langer's contributions extend to multiple key areas, including biotechnology, immobilized enzymes, and neural interfaces. His involvement with the Center for Innovative Minimally Invasive Therapy (CIMIT) underscores his commitment to advancing healthcare technologies that improve patient outcomes. With a focus on cutting-edge solutions such as cell membrane penetration and multielectrode arrays, Professor Langer's work not only enhances the understanding of complex biomedical challenges but also translates into practical applications that benefit society at large. His research continues to inspire innovations that aim to improve drug delivery systems and therapeutic strategies in the medical field.

summary: Dr. Allroggen has a background in Economics. His research brings together Transport Economics, Environmental Economics, and related research questions in Energy Economics. In his recent work, he focuses on understanding the transition of transportation to
fullText: Dr. Florian Allroggen serves as a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, where he leverages his extensive background in Economics to address pressing challenges at the intersection of transportation, energy, and the environment. His research expertise encompasses Transport Economics and Environmental Economics, with a particular emphasis on Sustainable Energy for Aviation. Dr. Allroggen is committed to advancing knowledge in these fields by conducting rigorous analyses that inform policy and industry practices. In his recent work, Dr. Allroggen focuses on the transition of transportation systems, exploring innovative solutions that enhance sustainability in aviation. His research contributions include life-cycle analyses and techno-economic assessments that evaluate the economic impacts of aviation and facilitate cost-benefit analyses. Additionally, he is proficient in aviation network modeling, which further enriches his insights into the complexities of transport systems. With a comprehensive understanding of the economic dimensions of both transport and energy sectors, Dr. Allroggen plays a pivotal role in shaping sustainable practices that address environmental concerns while promoting economic viability.

fullText: Sebastian Eastham is a Visiting Associate Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive expertise in Earth systems and atmospheric modeling to advance understanding of the impacts of anthropogenic emissions. With a strong focus on climate policy and air quality, Eastham applies high-resolution computational models of the atmosphere in conjunction with Earth observations to investigate and mitigate the atmospheric effects of human activities. His work is crucial for informing policy scenarios aimed at reducing emissions and improving public health. Eastham's research encompasses a range of critical areas, including the atmospheric modeling of combustion emissions, the dynamics of multi-sector interactions, and the development and application of multi-scale computational models. By integrating chemistry and dynamics into his simulations, he provides valuable insights that support effective climate policy formulation. His contributions are instrumental in addressing the complex challenges posed by air quality and climate change, positioning him as a leading figure in advancing sustainable practices and environmental stewardship.

His expertise encompasses a wide range of areas, including combustion processes, emissions reduction strategies, and the development of advanced computational techniques. Through his research, he seeks to bridge the gap between theoretical models and practical applications, ultimately driving progress in the field of sustainable energy and contributing to a more sustainable future.

fullText: Dr. Prashanth Prakash is a dedicated Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the development of sustainable aviation systems. With a strong focus on reducing the environmental impact of air travel, his work integrates technological innovation and policy development to promote a vibrant and inclusive aviation ecosystem aimed at achieving near-zero emissions. Dr. Prakash’s research is pivotal in addressing the pressing challenges of climate change within the aviation sector, reinforcing his commitment to creating a sustainable future. Additionally, Dr. Prakash is skilled in global chemistry transport modeling, which aids in understanding the broader implications of aviation emissions on the environment. Through his interdisciplinary research efforts, he contributes valuable insights and advancements that support the aviation industry’s transition towards environmentally responsible practices.

title: Assistant Professor of Biology
summary: One of the longstanding challenges that accounts for high cancer mortality is the failure to effectively eradicate subpopulations of cancer cells that are highly metastatic, therapy-resistant, and therefore critical instigators of tumor relapse. Ferroptos
fullText: Whitney Henry serves as an Assistant Professor of Biology at MIT, where she specializes in the study of ferroptosis and its implications for cancer biology and fatty liver disease. With a robust academic background and a commitment to understanding the mechanisms of cell death, Dr. Henry is at the forefront of research aimed at addressing one of the most significant challenges in oncology: the eradication of metastatic, therapy-resistant cancer cells that contribute to tumor relapse and high mortality rates. Dr. Henry's research focuses on elucidating the complex pathways involved in ferroptosis, a regulated form of cell death that may offer novel therapeutic strategies for targeting resilient cancer cell subpopulations. Her work seeks to bridge the gap between fundamental biological processes and clinical applications, providing insights that could lead to more effective cancer treatments. In addition to her research in cancer, Dr. Henry is also exploring the role of ferroptosis in fatty liver disease, further expanding her expertise in cellular metabolism and its implications for human health. Through her innovative research and dedication to teaching, Dr. Henry is making significant contributions to the fields of cancer biology and metabolic disorders.

title: Associate Professor of Biology
summary: The goal of the Spranger lab is to understand the molecular mechanisms of a range of tumor cell-intrinsic, tissue-specific or environmental factors directly impacting the interaction between cancer and the immune system. Understanding which permutations a
fullText: Stefani Spranger is an Associate Professor of Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she specializes in the fields of cancer immunology and personalized medicine. With a strong commitment to advancing our understanding of cancer biology, Dr. Spranger leads a dynamic research laboratory dedicated to exploring the molecular mechanisms that govern the interactions between tumor cells and the immune system. Her work is pivotal in elucidating how intrinsic tumor factors, as well as tissue-specific and environmental influences, affect these critical interactions, ultimately aiming to enhance therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. Through her innovative research, Dr. Spranger has made significant contributions to the field of cancer immunology, particularly in understanding how different permutations of tumor characteristics can shape immune responses. Her expertise in personalized medicine allows her to investigate tailored approaches for cancer therapies, ensuring that treatments are optimized for individual patient profiles. Dr. Spranger's commitment to uncovering the complexities of cancer-immune dynamics positions her as a leading voice in the pursuit of effective and personalized cancer therapies, making her an invaluable asset to the scientific community and a key figure in the ongoing fight against cancer.
